oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Lincoln School: classroom
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: West, Carroll Van
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Old TN 28 near Rockford Rd, Pikeville, Bledsoe Co., TN

Color photograph of a classroom with eight desks facing a blackboard on the wall and a green teacher's desk at the front of the room. Chairs line the border of the room. A portrait of Martin Luther King Jr. is on the blackboard and a painting of two farmers above the blackboard. The wall are covered in pressed tin, painted white.

Built 1925-26, the Lincoln School was a public school for African Americans and the only school built in Bledsoe County with funding from the Rosenwald Fund. It followed the four-teacher school plan specified by the Foundation. The Rosenwald program emphasized self-help and industrial education and the well-equipped school offered a new educational experience to area children. Lincoln School was the only school for African American children in Pikeville until 1965, following the court-ordered end to segregated facilities.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: African American schools -- Tennessee
